article_title: Cancer patient finds cheaper premium carries a high cost
article_text:
Cancer patient finds cheaper premium carries a high cost

Photo: Marie D. De Jesus, Staff Joshua Batiste's oncologist, Dr. Sahba Nadeem, has twice treated...

At $81.50 a month, the Blue Cross Blue Shield of Texas health plan Joshua Batiste bought through the federally mandated insurance marketplace appeared to provide the coverage a healthy man of his age would need at an affordable price.

article_metadata.description: [...] shortly after the plan took effect in January 2014, the self-employed software engineer was diagnosed with a skin cancer, a lymphoma that his doctor now fears has spread to his bone marrow.  [...] he found out his insurance plan, an HMO with a narrow provider network, didn't include the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, the world-renowned research hospital in his hometown, where his oncologist wants him to go for evaluation and possibly a stem-cell transplant.  [...] more than half of those sold through the marketplace are designed to keep premiums low and one way to do that is to keep high-profile hospitals such as M.D. Anderson out of their networks.  "What we find often is people don't necessarily look at what insurance covers first," said Erin Singleton, chief of missionary delivery at the nonprofit organization Patient Advocate Foundation, which helps about 88,000 patients across the country with life-threatening conditions sort out insurance coverage.  To keep prices low and competitive, insurers design narrow network plans, restricting consumers' ability to go to high-priced doctors and hospitals and limiting the insurer's financial exposure when patients become ill.  A 2013 report by the Washington, D.C.-based nonpartisan policy research organization Center for Studying Health System Change determined the highest-priced hospitals within a health care market typically are paid 60 percent more for the same inpatient services than the lowest-priced hospital.  "The dramatic variation in prices from one hospital to another points to the significant market power of certain hospitals to command high prices, even in markets with a dominant insurer," study author and senior researcher Chapin White said in a written statement.  Ken Janda, president and CEO of Community Health Choice, one of the Houston area's largest managed care providers, said it's tough to design robust provider network plans at costs low enough to attract consumers, especially low-income, working families who need insurance.  A single-minded focus on price sometimes ends up costing consumers more in the long run.  Besides offering fewer provider choices, high-deductible plans with cheaper premiums can become more expensive if consumers are chronically ill and require a lot of medical care and doctor appointments.
article_metadata.author.name: By Lora Hines
